member.name: M:Sharpmake.Assembler.CleanupTmpAssemblies
member.summary: This method is intended to be called at executable init time. It let us avoid exceptions when executing sharpmake several times in loops(exception can occur in the cs compiler when it tries to create pdb files and some already exists. Maybe that previous sharpmake sometimes still has some handles to the file?). With this cleanup code active there is no exception anymore on my PC. Previously I had the exception almost 100% on the second or third iteration of a stability test(executing sharpmake in loop to insure it always generate the same thing).
member.remarks: Was previously having the following exception when running stability tests(on subsequents sharpmake execution runs): Unexpected error creating debug information file 'c:\Users\xxxx\AppData\Local\Temp\Sharpmake.Assembler_1.tmp.PDB' -- 'c:\Users\xxxx\AppData\Local\Temp\Sharpmake.Assembler_1.tmp.pdb: The process cannot access the file because it is being used by another process.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.ConfigurePriority
member.summary:
This method attribute is used to specify the execution order of Configure(...) within a project or a solution generation
If this attribute is not set a default value a 0 is used
The configure methods using this property are sorted ascendingly. ex: ... -1 before 0 before 1 ...
See Configure method attribute and Configurable class for more details

member.name: T:Sharpmake.CompositeFragmentAttribute
member.summary: Marks elements of fragments that should not be considered individual fragments.
member.remarks: When an enumeration is marked with , Sharpmake normally ensure that each element sets 1 and only 1 bit. However, it is often useful in a bit enum to combine multiple bits together to create sets that go well together. To prevent Sharpmake from considering those errors, you must decorate these enum members with .

member.name: T:Sharpmake.ExtensionLoader
member.summary: Helper for loading Sharpmake extensions.
member.remarks: Normally, this should be done using reflection-only load, but the problem is that you have to resolve the dependencies yourself. Turns out that it's simpler to actually let the CLR do a full load in a temporary that we can trash later.

member.summary: Gets whether an assembly is a Sharpmake extension.

member.returns: `true` if it is an extension, `false` otherwise.
member.remarks: This method will instantiate a remote if none was created.

member.name: M:Sharpmake.ExtensionLoader.LoadExtension(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads a Sharpmake extension assembly.
member.param: The path of the assembly that contains the Sharpmake extension.
Whether this method should load the assembly remotely first. See remarks.
member.returns: The loaded extension's .
member.remarks: Because loading an extension in a remote assembly for validation is expensive, this method provides the argument which, when `false`, will load the extension in the current instead of doing so in a remote , testing whether it contains , and then loading it again in . However, because it is impossible to unload a loaded assembly from the CLR, if this method fail you have essentially polluted the process' address space with an assembly that you may not need.

member.param: The path to the directory to scan for assemblies.
member.returns: A that contains the loaded .

member.name: P:Sharpmake.Util.VsInstallation.ProductID
member.summary: The full list of products can be found here: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/install/workload-and-component-ids

member.name: P:Sharpmake.Util.VsInstallation.Workloads
member.summary:
This can be used to check and limit by specific installed workloads.
What is a Workload? In the VS installer, a 'Workload' is a section that you see in the UI such as 'Desktop development with C++' or '.NET desktop development'.
The full list of products is here: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/install/workload-and-component-ids
For each product, clicking it will bring up a page of all of the possible Workloads. For example: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/install/workload-component-id-vs-professional

member.name: P:Sharpmake.Util.VsInstallation.Components
member.summary:
This can be used to check and limit by specific installed components. What is a Component? In the Visual Studio Installer, the 'Components' are individual components associated with each Workload (and some just on the side), that you can see in the Summary on the right. Each workflow contains a number of mandatory components, but also a list of optional ones. An example would be: 'NuGet package manager' or 'C++/CLI support'.
The full list of products is here: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/install/workload-and-component-ids
For each product, clicking it will bring up a page of all of the possible Workloads. For example: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/install/workload-component-id-vs-professional

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Util.s_supportedVisualStudioProducts
member.summary:
The supported visual studio products, in order by priority in which Sharpmake will choose them. We want to block products like the standalone Team Explorer, which is in the Visual Studio family yet isn't a variant of Visual Studio proper.
The list of Product IDs can be found here: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/install/workload-and-component-ids

member.name: F:Sharpmake.FastBuildSettings.SetPathToResourceCompilerInEnvironment
member.summary:
link.exe on win64 executes rc.exe by itself on some occasions if it doesn't find it, link errors can occur, like: fatal error LNK1158: cannot run rc.exe!
Setting this to true will have sharpmake detect if a rc.exe can be found in the same folder as link.exe, and if not add the path to one in the global settings Environment section, in the PATH variable

member.name: T:Sharpmake.PlatformRegistry
member.summary: Global registry that maps platform-specific implementations of interfaces with a concrete implementation. This facility allows to add and remove platform-specific generators without having to break any code.
member.remarks: This class searches for implementations using .NET reflection when the type is loaded by looking for types marked with in assemblies marked with . It may also store default implementations to fall-back to when it does not find any implementation for a requested platform and interface. Default implementations must be marked with .

member.name: T:Sharpmake.DependencySetting
member.summary: Options to specify the properties of the dependencies between projects. This is used with and .

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencySetting.OnlyBuildOrder
member.summary: The dependent project must be built after the dependency. Otherwise the two files have no dependencies.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencySetting.LibraryFiles
member.summary: The dependent project inherits the library files of the dependency. Valid only when the project is a C or a C++ project.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencySetting.LibraryPaths
member.summary: The dependent project inherits the library paths of the dependency. Valid only when the project is a C or a C++ project.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencySetting.IncludePaths
member.summary: The dependent project inherits the include paths of the dependency. Valid only when the project is a C or a C++ project.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencySetting.Defines
member.summary: The dependent project inherits the defined symbols of the dependency. Valid only when the project is a C or a C++ project.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencySetting.AdditionalUsingDirectories
member.summary: The dependent project inherits the `using` paths of the dependency. Valid only if the project is a C# project and uses Microsoft C++/CX extensions .

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencySetting.Default
member.summary: Specifies that the dependent project inherits the dependency's library files, library paths, include paths and defined symbols.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencySetting.DefaultWithoutLinking
member.summary: Specifies that the dependent project inherits the dependency's include paths and defined symbols, but not it's library files or library paths. Use this for header-only C++ libraries.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.DependencyType
member.summary: Visibility types for inter-project dependency relationships. This setting is usually only meaningful in cases where a library depends on another library because one of its executables has an end-point in the other's dependency graph.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencyType.Private
member.summary: Specifies that the dependency relationship is private. The dependent project will not expose the dependency's exported properties, such as it's include paths.
member.remarks: A library that has a private dependency relationship with another library will use that library internally when compiled but will not expose the private dependency's exported properties (library paths, include paths, etc.) when other projects link to it. For example, if library B has a private dependency on C and A wants to link to B, A will not inherit any of C's include paths, library paths, etc.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencyType.Public
member.summary: Specifies that the dependency relationship is public. The dependent project will expose the dependency's exported properties as it's own.
member.remarks: A library that has a public dependency relationship with another library will expose that dependency's include paths, library paths, etc. to any project that has a public dependency on it. For example, if library B has a public dependency on C and A wants to link to B, A will inherit all of C's include paths, library paths, etc.

member.name: P:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.Output
member.summary: Gets or sets the output type of the current configuration, exe, lib or dll.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.OutputExtension
member.summary: Gets or sets the project's output extension (ie: .dll, .self, .exe, .dlu).

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.ExecuteTargetCopy
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to copy output files to the output directory.
member.remarks:
This setting is provided for libraries, because they are usually intermediate artifacts during the compilation process and do not need to be in the final output directory unless it's necessary.
The default is false. Setting this to true will force the generators to copy the library artifacts.
If is set to a value that corresponds to an executable program (ie: ), the generators disregard this property and always copy the results.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CopyCompilerPdbToDependentTargets
member.summary: Gets or sets whether dependent projects will copy their debugging database to the target path of their dependency projects. The default value is false.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.TargetCopyCommandCreator
member.summary: Command to execute .
member.param: The relative path to the files.
The relative path to the target directory.
The path to the working directory.
member.returns: The mapped value as a string.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.ExportAdditionalLibrariesEvenForStaticLib
member.summary: Setting this boolean to true forces Sharpmake to fill in the AD fields in the current static library project.
member.remarks:
Since Sharpmake handles all dependencies, using an AdditionalDependencies field in your project is typically useless for static libraries. However, when dependents aren't generated by Sharpmake, (that is, when a .sln contains Sharpmake generated projects as static libraries as well as manually maintained dependent projects) this feature can be useful.
The default is false. Set this boolean to true to make Sharpmake fill in the fields for the current static library project.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.ProjectName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the project, as viewed by the configuration.
member.remarks: Under normal circumstances, you should not need to edit this property. The name of the project is set in and this is the default value.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.ProjectFileName

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.ProjectPath

member.remarks: By default, this is set to the same directory that this Sharpmake script is running in.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.AssemblyName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the generated .NET assembly.
member.remarks: Ignored in projects that are not built on the .NET framework.

member.name: P:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.ProjectFullFileName
member.summary: Gets the full path of the project file, including the directory and the file name. This doesn't include the file extension which depends on the generator.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.SolutionFolder
member.summary: Gets or sets the solution folder that will hold the Visual Studio solution for this project.
member.remarks:
Ignored unless building a Visual Studio project.
To place the project in a sub-directory, use a `/` as a directory separator.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.LinkerPdbSuffix
member.summary: Gets or sets the suffix to use in . If unset, the pdb file names will be the target name with a suffix and the .pdb extension.
member.remarks: Always put a separate pdb for the compiler in the intermediate path to avoid conflicts with the one from the linker. This helps the following things: 1. Makes the linker go faster 2. Avoid pdbs for dlls and .exe(s) growing and growing at each link 3. Makes incremental linking work better.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.LinkerPdbFilePath
member.summary: Gets or sets the directory and file name of the Visual Studio *linker* PDB file, including the file extension.
member.remarks:
Used only when generating a Visual Studio project.
The default value is: [conf.TargetPath]/[conf.TargetFileFullName][conf.LinkerPdbSuffix].pdb.
Always put a separate PDB for the compiler in the intermediate path to avoid conflicts with the one from the linker.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CompilerPdbSuffix
member.summary: Gets or sets the suffix to use in .
member.remarks: Provided only as a convenience as it is only used in the default value of to assign a suffix to the PDB. If you change so that it doesn't use this property, then it isn't used.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CompilerPdbFilePath
member.summary: Gets or sets the directory and file name of the Visual Studio compiler PDB file, including the file extension.
member.remarks:
Used only when generating a Visual Studio project.
The default value is [conf.IntermediatePath]/[conf.TargetFileFullName][conf.CompilerPdbSuffix].pdb.
The default file name in in Sharpmake does not match its default file name in Visual Studio for compiler PDB, which is VCx0.pdb. See /Fd (Program Database File Name) https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/9wst99a9.aspx . If you mean to use Visual Studio's default value, you must set this property to null.
Always put a separate PDB for the compiler in the intermediate path to avoid conflicts with the one from the linker.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.UseRelativePdbPath
member.summary: Gets or sets whether and are relative.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.ManifestFileSuffix
member.summary: Gets or sets the suffix of the manifests when building a project that uses Microsoft's C++/CX with the build option *Embed Manifest*.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.EmbeddedResourceOutputPrefix
member.summary: Prefix for compiled embedded resource files

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.IntermediatePath
member.summary: Gets or sets the directory where the compiler will place the intermediate files.
member.remarks:
This corresponds to the Intermediate directory in the Visual Studio project configuration.
The default value is [conf.ProjectPath]/obj/[target.Platform].

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.BaseIntermediateOutputPath
member.summary: Base Intermediate devEnv directory. Only used in csproj

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.Defines
member.summary: Gets the list of defined symbols to use when compiling the project.
member.remarks:
Generators are allowed to add new symbols to this list when needed. For example, you don't need to explicitly add _WIN32 to the list when building for Windows.
These symbols are defined during the compilation, not when the project is used as a library. The symbols that need to be defined when this project is being consumed as a library, must be added to instead.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.ExportDefines
member.summary: Gets the list of symbols that are exported when the project is being used as a library.
member.remarks:
Not used if the project is not a library.
The symbols defined in this list are not defined when building the library. You must define them in .

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.SourceFilesBuildExclude

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.AdditionalCompilerOptions
member.summary: Gets a list of compiler options to send when calling the compiler.
member.remarks:
Generators are allowed to transform the textual representation of the options added here so that they work with the shell of the operating system or with the makefile format.
The values in this list are simply concatenated, separated with spaces, sanitized for the shell, and then appended directly to the command that calls the compiler.
They are not translated from one compiler to the other. When you use this property, you need to know which C++ compiler you're using.
This property is for the compiler. Its counterpart for the linker is .

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.PrecompSource
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the source file for the precompiled header in C and C++ projects, ie: stdafx.cpp. This property must be null for projects that don't have a precompiled header.
member.remarks:
Both and must be null if the project doesn't have precompiled headers.
Sharpmake assumes that a relative path here is relative to . If that isn't correct, you must use an absolute path.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.PrecompHeader
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the precompiled header in C and C++ projects, ie: stdafx.h. This property must be null for projects that do not have a precompiled header.
member.remarks:
Both and must be null if the project doesn't have precompiled headers.
Sharpmake assumes that any relative path entered here is relative to . If that isn't correct, you must use an absolute path.
The source files must manually include this header or you will have compiler errors. Sharpmake merely tells the compiler to expect a precompiled header. The compiler doesn't implicitly include the header.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.PrecompHeaderOutputFolder
member.summary: Gets or sets the output directory for the precompiled header's binary file in C and C++ projects.
member.remarks:
If this property is set to null, Sharpmake will simply write the binary file to , the same as the object file.
If defined, precompiled headers are written to this directory instead of the intermediate directory.

member.summary: Gets a list of the static libraries to link to.
member.remarks:
This should only be used for third party libraries that are not part of the compiled source code. Libraries that are part of the compiled source code should be included by calling either
or . This makes things much easier because Sharpmake will automatically take care of setting the library paths, library files, include paths, and build order according to the dependency graph.
Unless your library name contains a .(dot) in its file name, you don't need to add the file extension of any library you add here. If you do, Sharpmake will automatically remove it.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CustomFileBuildStepData
member.summary: This is all the data specific to a custom build step. The ones stored in the project configuration use absolute paths but we need relative paths when we're ready to export a specific project file.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CustomFileBuildStepData.ProjectFilter
member.summary: This lets us filter which type of project files should have this custom build step. This is specifically used to deal with the limitations of different build systems.
member.remarks:
Visual studio only supports one build action per file, so if you need both compilation and some other build steps such as QT or Documentation generation on the same file, you need to put the rule on a different input file that also depends on the real input file.
FASTBuild is key based, not file based. So it can have two different operations on the same file. If you need support for FASTBuild, you can make two different custom build rules with one specific to BFF and the other excluding BFF.

member.summary: The custom build step is specific to BFF

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.StartWorkingDirectory
member.summary: Gets or sets the working directory when a C# project is started from Visual Studio.

members.member:
Defines where the compiler will generate an XML documentation file at compile time.
The compiler generated XML file can be distributed alongside your .NET assembly so that Visual Studio and other IDEs can use IntelliSense to show quick information about types or members. Additionally, the XML file can be run through tools like DocFX and Sandcastle to generate API reference websites
The following will output an XML file in the target directory with the same root filename as the assembly
conf.XmlDocumentationFile = @"[conf.TargetPath]\[project.AssemblyName].xml";
C# only

member.name: T:Sharpmake.OrderableStrings
member.summary: Same as Strings but support to specify additionally an order number for every entry. Every entry has by default the value 0. Putting negative values will result in the entries to be first after a sort, putting positive will result in the entries to be last after a sort. Order numbers are kept when copying container to another OrderableStrings. It is forbidden to specify 2 different non-zero order numbers for the exact same string in 2 merged together OrderableStrings.

member.remarks:
The method should be non-static and conform to one of the supported signatures:
NotifyChanged(string)
NotifyChanged(params string[])
NotifyChanged{T}(Expression{Func{T}})
NotifyChanged{T,U}(Expression{Func{T,U}})
SetProperty{T}(ref T, T, string)

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ContractAnnotationAttribute
member.summary: Describes dependency between method input and output.
member.syntax:
Function Definition Table syntax:
FDT ::= FDTRow [;FDTRow]*
FDTRow ::= Input => Output | Output <= Input
Input ::= ParameterName: Value [, Input]*
Output ::= [ParameterName: Value]* {halt|stop|void|nothing|Value}
Value ::= true | false | null | notnull | canbenull
If method has single input parameter, it's name could be omitted.
Using halt (or void/nothing, which is the same) for method output means that the methos doesn't return normally (throws or terminates the process).
Value canbenull is only applicable for output parameters.
You can use multiple [ContractAnnotation] for each FDT row, or use single attribute with rows separated by semicolon. There is no notion of order rows, all rows are checked for applicability and applied per each program state tracked by R# analysis.

item.code: [ContractAnnotation("halt <= condition: false")] public void Assert(bool condition, string text) // regular assertion method
[ContractAnnotation("s:null => true")] public bool IsNullOrEmpty(string s) // string.IsNullOrEmpty()
[ContractAnnotation("=> true, result: notnull; => false, result: null")] public bool TryParse(string s, out Person result)

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.SourceTemplateAttribute
member.summary: An extension method marked with this attribute is processed by ReSharper code completion as a 'Source Template'. When extension method is completed over some expression, it's source code is automatically expanded like a template at call site.
member.remarks: Template method body can contain valid source code and/or special comments starting with '$'. Text inside these comments is added as source code when the template is applied. Template parameters can be used either as additional method parameters or as identifiers wrapped in two '$' signs. Use the attribute to specify macros for parameters.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.MacroAttribute
member.summary: Allows specifying a macro for a parameter of a source template.
member.remarks: You can apply the attribute on the whole method or on any of its additional parameters. The macro expression is defined in the property. When applied on a method, the target template parameter is defined in the property. To apply the macro silently for the parameter, set the property value = -1.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Annotations.MacroAttribute.Expression
member.summary: Allows specifying a macro that will be executed for a source template parameter when the template is expanded.

members.member:
Allows specifying which occurrence of the target parameter becomes editable when the template is deployed.
If the target parameter is used several times in the template, only one occurrence becomes editable; other occurrences are changed synchronously. To specify the zero-based index of the editable occurrence, use values >= 0. To make the parameter non-editable when the template is expanded, use -1. >

member.name: P:JetBrains.Annotations.MacroAttribute.Target
member.summary: Identifies the target parameter of a source template if the is applied on a template method.
